title: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day
author: William Shakespeare

poemIntroduction.text:
Shakespeare was a respected poet and playwright in his own day, but his reputation did not rise to its present heights until the 19th century. The Romantics, in particular, acclaimed Shakespeare's genius, and the Victorians worshipped Shakespeare with a reverence that George Bernard Shaw called bardolatry.
In the 20th century, his work was repeatedly adopted and rediscovered by new movements in scholarship and performance. His plays remain highly popular today and are constantly studied, performed, and reinterpreted in diverse cultural and political contexts throughout the world.
(from wiki)

authorIntroduction.text: Shakespeare was a respected poet and playwright in his own day, but his reputation did not rise to its present heights until the 19th century

poembody.text: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?

translated.chinese: 能不能让我来把你比拟做夏日?

explanation.thee: Thee is an old-fashioned, poetic, or religious word for "you" when you are talking to only one person. It is used as the object of a verb or preposition

poembody.text: Thou art more lovely and more temperate

translated.chinese: 你可是更加温和,更加可爱

explanation.Thou: Thou is an old-fashioned, poetic, or religious word for "you" when you are talking to only one person. It is used as the subject of a verb

poembody.extra: 这句表达了什么什么什么

poembody.text: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May

translated.chinese: 狂风会吹落五月里开的好花儿

poembody.text: And summer's lease hath all too short a date

translated.chinese: 夏季的生命又未免结束得太快

poembody.text: Sometimes too hot the eys of heaven shines

translated.chinese: 有时候苍天的巨眼照得太灼热

poembody.text: And often is his gold complexion dimmed

translated.chinese: 他那金彩的脸色也会被遮暗

poembody.text: And every fair from fair somethme declines

translated.chinese: 每一样美呀,总会离开美而凋落

poembody.text: By chance, or nature's changing course, untrimmed

translated.chinese: 被时机或者自然的代谢所摧残

poembody.text: But thy eternal summer shall not fade

translated.chinese: 但是你永久的夏天决不会凋枯

poembody.text: Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest

translated.chinese: 你永远不会失去你美的仪态

poembody.text: Nor shall Death brag thou wanderest in his shade

translated.chinese: 死神夸不着你在他的影子里踯躅

poembody.text: When in eternal lines to time thou growest

translated.chinese: 你将在不朽的诗中与时间同在

poembody.text: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see

translated.chinese: 只要人类在呼吸,眼睛看得见

poembody.text: So long lives this, and this gives life to thee

translated.chinese: 我这诗就活着,使你的生命绵延

poemIntroduction.text:
Anne Killigrew (1660—1685) was an English poet. Born in London, Killigrew is perhaps best known as the subject of a famous elegy by the poet John Dryden entitled To The Pious Memory of the Accomplish'd Young Lady Mrs. Anne Killigrew (1686). 
She was however a skilful poet in her own right, and her Poems were published posthumously in 1686. Dryden compared her poetic abilities to the famous Greek poet of antiquity, Sappho. Killigrew died of smallpox aged 25.
(from wiki)

authorIntroduction.text: Anne Killigrew (1660—1685) was an English poet. Born in London, Killigrew is perhaps best known as the subject of a famous elegy by the poet John Dryden entitled To The Pious Memory of the Accomplish'd Young Lady Mrs. Anne Killigrew (1686). She was however a skilful poet in her own right, and her Poems were published posthumously in 1686. Dryden compared her poetic abilities to the famous Greek poet of antiquity, Sappho. Killigrew died of smallpox aged 25

poembody.text: Farewel to Unsubstantial Joyes

translated.chinese: 永别了,空洞的欢乐

poembody.text: Ye Gilded Nothings,Gaudy Toyes

translated.chinese: 太久,给它空气般的米黍

explanation.Ye: Ye was the second-person, plural, personal pronoun (nominative), spelled in Old English as "ge". In Middle English and Early Modern English, it was used to address an equal or superior person.

poembody.extra: 这句表达了什么什么什么

poembody.text: Too long ye have my Soul misled

translated.chinese: 太久,你使我的灵魂迷途

poembody.text: Too long with Aiery Diet fed

translated.chinese: 夏季的生命又未免结束得太快

poembody.text: But now my Heart ye shall no more

translated.chinese: 但是我的心不会再被你迷惑

explanation.ye: Ye is an old-fashioned, poetic, or religious word for when you are talking to more than one person

poembody.text: And often is his gold complexion dimmed

translated.chinese: 他那金彩的脸色也会被遮暗

poembody.text: And every fair from fair somethme declines

translated.chinese: 每一样美呀,总会离开美而凋落

poembody.text: By chance, or nature's changing course, untrimmed

translated.chinese: 被时机或者自然的代谢所摧残

poembody.text: But thy eternal summer shall not fade

translated.chinese: 但是你永久的夏天决不会凋枯

poembody.text: Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest

translated.chinese: 你永远不会失去你美的仪态

poembody.text: Nor shall Death brag thou wanderest in his shade

translated.chinese: 死神夸不着你在他的影子里踯躅

poembody.text: When in eternal lines to time thou growest

translated.chinese: 你将在不朽的诗中与时间同在

poembody.text: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see

translated.chinese: 只要人类在呼吸,眼睛看得见

poembody.text: So long lives this, and this gives life to thee

translated.chinese: 我这诗就活着,使你的生命绵延

explanation.thee: Thee is an old-fashioned, poetic, or religious word for "you" when you are talking to only one person. It is used as the object of a verb or preposition

poemIntroduction.text:
William Blake (28 November 1757 – 12 August 1827) was an English painter, poet and printmaker. Largely unrecognised during his lifetime, Blake is now considered a seminal figure in the history of the poetry and visual arts of the Romantic Age. His prophetic poetry has been said to form "what is in proportion to its merits the least read body of poetry in the English language".
His visual artistry led one contemporary art critic to proclaim him "far and away the greatest artist Britain has ever produced".In 2002, Blake was placed at number 38 in the BBC's poll of the 100 Greatest Britons.[3] Although he lived in London his entire life (except for three years spent in Felpham),he produced a diverse and symbolically rich oeuvre, which embraced the imagination as "the body of God" or "human existence itself"
(from wiki)

poembody.text: I dreamt a dream! What can it mean?

translated.chinese: 我做了一个梦!意味着什么?

poembody.text: And that I was a maiden Queen

translated.chinese: 我是一个未婚的女王

poembody.extra: 这句表达了什么什么什么

poembody.text: Guarded by an Angel mild

translated.chinese: 被一个温存的天使守护着

poembody.text: Witless woe was ne'er beguiled!

translated.chinese: 我从未被愚蠢的悲伤所迷惑!

poembody.text: And he wiped my tears away

translated.chinese: 天使为我擦去了眼泪

poembody.text: And hid from him my heart's delight

translated.chinese: 可是我整天里都在啼哭

poembody.text: And he wiped my tears away

translated.chinese: 其实我对他隐瞒了心头的喜悦

poembody.text: So he took his wings, and fled

translated.chinese: 以致他展开翅膀飞逝地离我而去

poembody.text: Then the morn blushed rosy red

translated.chinese: 于是在早晨的天空里留下了玫瑰的红色

poembody.text: I dried my tears, and armed my fears with ten-thousand shields and spears

translated.chinese:
我擦干了泪水,拿起了上万个盾牌和剑戟
迎击着内心的恐慌和惊吓

poembody.text: Soon my Angel came again

translated.chinese: 不久我的天使再次来到我身边

poembody.text: I was armed, he came in vain

translated.chinese: 可是我全副武装,他也徒劳无益

poembody.text: For the time of youth was fled

translated.chinese: 因为青春年华已飞逝而去

poembody.text: And grey hairs were on my head.

translated.chinese: 我已长出了灰白的头发
